webTitle: UK services sector contracts: what the economists say

fields.standfirst: There was a surprise contraction in UK services activity in December, putting Britain on the road to a triple-dip recession. Separate Bank of England figures showed the biggest monthly rise in mortgage approvals since January 2012
fields.body:
Vicky Redwood, Capital Economics

Although the floods may have hampered business in some parts, we expect that the aggregate impact was pretty minor. What's more, the temporary influences on the economy in the past few months (such as June's extra bank holiday or the Olympic Games) seem to have had less of an effect on the surveys than on the official data. Accordingly, the weakness of the surveys appears to reflect more of an underlying problem.

Rob Harbron, Centre for Economics and Business Research

Mitigating the service sector decline to some extent, the manufacturing sector gave more positive news for December. The headline PMI for the sector rose to indicate an output expansion for the first time in nine months, driven by the volume of new orders rising at the quickest rate since March 2011. Despite this, there are signs that UK manufacturers are struggling to capture overseas demand, as new export orders have now been falling for a full year.

An export-led manufacturing recovery still looks tricky to achieve. Employment prospects in the UK's private sector remain tough, as both the manufacturing and service sectors reported no net increase in job numbers in December. With public sector job cuts continuing, upward pressure on unemployment is likely in 2013. Overall, the latest PMI results illustrate the difficult conditions that UK businesses continue to face.

Howard Archer, IHS Global Insight

This is undeniably a very disappointing survey which fuels fears the economy suffered a renewed dip in GDP in the fourth quarter. Given the dominant role of the services sector and the fact that it has recently been the healthiest part of the UK economy on the output side, the reported fall in activity in December is a significant blow for growth hopes.

While the weak services purchasing managers' survey is unlikely to prompt the Bank of England's monetary policy committee into taking any stimulative [action] at its January meeting next week, it does reinforce our belief that further quantitative easing is more likely than not over the coming months. For now though, the MPC is likely to sit tight given current increased inflation concerns and signs that the Funding for Lending scheme could be increasing having a beneficial impact.

David Tinsley, BNP Paribas

The fourth quarter was also always likely to look fairly soft, given the levels-correction from the Olympics in Q3 dropping away. The key now is the direction of travel in the early months of 2013. One cause for more optimism here is this week's Credit Conditions Survey and today's mortgage approvals data.

Robert Wood, Berenberg Bank

A big thing that is not often picked up from these PMI indicators is that future business expectations remain very weak and point to contraction in Q1 2013. This is a story of the first half, with the UK flat-lining. But as we head into the second half of the year, we still expect the UK to return to gradual growth, in part as credit conditions ease with the [Funding for Lending scheme].

George Buckley, Deutsche Bank

We're going to need to see some better numbers than this if the Bank of England's forecast and the [Office for Budget Responsibility's] forecast for GDP during the course of 2013 are to be correct. This is too weak for those forecasts to come true and obviously raises the risk that we do get this triple dip and it's not just a single quarter of decline in Q4. It might well extend into 2013 if these PMIs stay where they are.

Peter Dixon, Commerzbank

If you look at the whole raft of PMI data which came out over the course of recent days, that's an indication of the extent to which the economy has lost momentum as we reached year-end. Whether or not it will pick up in the course of the next few months, we remain hopeful but we have to bear in mind that we're starting from a very weak base and there's not a lot we can do other than wait for a couple of months to see whether these things turn around.

I remain of the opinion that the Funding for Lending scheme simply means that the supply of mortgage credit has increased but I'm not convinced that there's a big appetite at the moment in an environment of household deleveraging for a big pickup in demand and I think the decline in mortgage lending in November reflects that lack of appetite.

Annalisa Piazza, Newedge Strategy

UK data were mixed, confirming the idea that the UK economy is not out of the woods yet. The services PMI index is now running at its lowest level since mid-09, when the UK economy was in a deep recession. We rule out that such a decline in activity will materialise near term but today's data certainly don't bode well for Q4 GDP.

As for the UK mortgage market, the Bank of England's mortgage approvals data … is broadly in line with expectations and it marks the strongest reading since January 2012. The BoE's credit conditions survey showed a substantial improvement in Q4-12 (report out on Thursday) and supply of credit is expected to continue to progress in the next three months or so. This is good news for the BoE as the Funding for Lending programme seems to work its way through the real economy, supporting the troublesome UK housing market.

While the weak services purchasing managers' survey is unlikely to prompt the Bank of England's monetary policy committee into taking any stimulative [action] at its January meeting next week, it does reinforce our belief that further quantitative easing is more likely than not over the coming months. For now though, the MPC is likely to sit tight given current increased inflation concerns and signs that the Funding for Lending scheme could be increasing having a beneficial impact. David Tinsley, BNP Paribas The fourth quarter was also always likely to look fairly soft, given the levels-correction from the Olympics in Q3 dropping away. The key now is the direction of travel in the early months of 2013. One cause for more optimism here is this week's Credit Conditions Survey and today's mortgage approvals data. This is a story of the first half, with the UK flat-lining. But as we head into the second half of the year, we still expect the UK to return to gradual growth, in part as credit conditions ease with the [Funding for Lending scheme]. This is too weak for those forecasts to come true and obviously raises the risk that we do get this triple dip and it's not just a single quarter of decline in Q4. It might well extend into 2013 if these PMIs stay where they are. Peter Dixon, Commerzbank If you look at the whole raft of PMI data which came out over the course of recent days, that's an indication of the extent to which the economy has lost momentum as we reached year-end. Whether or not it will pick up in the course of the next few months, we remain hopeful but we have to bear in mind that we're starting from a very weak base and there's not a lot we can do other than wait for a couple of months to see whether these things turn around. I remain of the opinion that the Funding for Lending scheme simply means that the supply of mortgage credit has increased but I'm not convinced that there's a big appetite at the moment in an environment of household deleveraging for a big pickup in demand and I think the decline in mortgage lending in November reflects that lack of appetite. Annalisa Piazza, Newedge Strategy UK data were mixed, confirming the idea that the UK economy is not out of the woods yet. The services PMI index is now running at its lowest level since mid-09, when the UK economy was in a deep recession. We rule out that such a decline in activity will materialise near term but today's data certainly don't bode well for Q4 GDP. As for the UK mortgage market, the Bank of England's mortgage approvals data … is broadly in line with expectations and it marks the strongest reading since January 2012. The BoE's credit conditions survey showed a substantial improvement in Q4-12 (report out on Thursday) and supply of credit is expected to continue to progress in the next three months or so. This is good news for the BoE as the Funding for Lending programme seems to work its way through the real economy, supporting the troublesome UK housing market.

webTitle: Marks & Spencer slips ahead of trading update

fields.standfirst: Analysts expect retailer's third quarter sales to fall back on weak general merchandise performance
fields.body:
With the Christmas trading updates beginning, retailers are increasingly in focus.

Ahead of its latest statement on Thursday, Marks & Spencer shares are coming under pressure, with analysts at Nomura cutting their full year forecasts from £694m to £666m.

The bank expects the update for the third quarter to show UK like for like sales down 1.4%, hit by weakness in its general merchandising offering. Analyst Fraser Ramzan said:

Market data from Kantar Worldpanel broadly suggested a 9% decline in clothing sales in October and a flat performance in November. We expect December sales to struggle against tough prior-year promotion-driven comparatives to make positive ground, despite some reports of strong retail sales in the week before Christmas. Assuming they are flat in December, this suggests general merchandise sales down 2.2% in the third quarter given the strong weighting of sales towards December in the quarter.
Food data has remained relatively robust. Assuming a 3% increase in December sales against a 5% rise last year, and with a demanding calendar (23 December, which is traditionally the most important trading day for M&S, had Sunday opening hours), this generates an expectation of a 3% total rise in third quarter food sales). In our view, M&S is changing trading stance from one driven by market share (and often promotion), to a more full-price-oriented approach. This will result in difficult quarters in top-line terms, but over time could help deliver a significant margin opportunity relative to peers.

M&S shares are currently down 11.4p at 377p, but rival Next has risen another 11p to £38.84 following Thursday's well received update.

Deutsche Bank issued a buy note on Next with a £42 target, while Societe Generale said:

Next remains attractive due to a strong focus on product, careful cost control and a well-established strategy of funding share buybacks through excess cash generation.

webTitle: FTSE 100 dips on UK data but BP boosted by Transocean deal

fields.standfirst: Mining groups come under pressure on worries about global economy with Fresnillo hit by downgrade
fields.body:
Mexican silver miner Fresnillo has lost its shine as leading shares paused for breath after the recent rally.

The company is the biggest faller in the FTSE 100 after analysts at UBS cut their rating from buy to neutral on valuation grounds. It lost 101p to £17.84 as the analysts said:

Since September 10, 2012, Fresnillo is up 7% versus silver down 9% and our average silver stock under coverage down 2%.
Despite the downgrade, we continue to believe Fresnillo shares offer attractive exposure if silver and gold prices move higher. Fresnillo holds a well diversified portfolio of high-quality silver and gold assets. However, it currently trades at 1.26 times net asset value and 18.7 times 2013 cash flow, 48% and 44% higher than the North American peer group, respectively.

Anglo American fell 36p to 1978.5p after it agreed to sell its joint venture Amapa iron ore mine in Brazil to a company controlled by former commodities trader Pramod Agarwal.

Other mining shares were also under pressure on worries about global growth. The latest catalyst was news from the US that Federal Reserve members were split on the duration of its quantitative easing programme, more so than had been thought. That has caused some uncertainty ahead of the US non-farm payroll numbers this afternoon, where analysts are expecting, on average, a gain of around 150,000 jobs. Rebecca O'Keeffe, head of investment at Interactive Investor, said:

The level of support provided through QE3 is the equivalent of life support and with the market dependent on this support continuing, any steps indicating that the machine will be turned off is bad news for investors.

The FTSE 100 is currently down 5.30 points at 6042.04, not helped by worse than expected UK services data for December. But contrary to some expectations, the market is holding on to the bulk of the gains made following the last minute US agreement which prevented the US falling off the so-called fiscal cliff, the mix of spending cuts and tax rises due to come into force in January.

Among the risers, BP has climbed 5.55p to 447.25p after rig contractor Transocean agreed to pay a lower than expected fine of $1.4bn to settle charges relating its role in the Gulf of Mexico oil disaster. Analysts at Exane BNP Paribas said:

We see the Transocean settlement with the Department of Justice, which covers civil and criminal penalties for the Macondo spill, as having a positive read-across for BP. Note that the settlement includes $1bn for the Clean Water Act but excludes Natural Resources Damages.
Crucially, under the agreement, Transocean has pleaded guilty to a single misdemeanour violation of the Clean Water Act for negligent discharge of oil. Given the proven multi-causal/multi-party nature of the incident, we believe that it could be difficult to pursue a "gross negligence" case against BP when the main contractor at the well is simply pleading guilty to "negligence".

Lower down the market Oxford Catalysts has jumped 7% to 155p following a report that Chelsea owner Roman Abramovich had taken a 3% stake in the oil and gas technology company as part of a £30.6m fundraising.
